pull_request.title: Remove round 2 Dilithium KATs
pull_request.body: The new naming scheme for Dilithium caused some old KATs to be left in sig/kats.json. This removes them.

pull_request.title: Changing python platform check
pull_request.body:
Fixes #901 

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding or removing?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

pull_request.title: Add OQS_MINIMAL_BUILD option
pull_request.body:
This adds an option to build only the default KEM and Signature scheme. For example, with this patch, if you want to build liboqs with only the Kyber512 and Dilithium2 algorithms you can use:
```
cmake -GNinja -DOQS_MINIMAL_BUILD=ON -DOQS_KEM_DEFAULT=OQS_KEM_alg_kyber_512 -DOQS_SIG_DEFAULT=OQS_SIG_alg_dilithium_2 ..
```

This will build the exact match for the default kem and sig and also any "_aesni" or "_avx2" implementations that are supported by the platform.

Opening this PR, at @baentsch's recommendation, for discussion about whether this is a useful feature / what else we would like it to do.

pull_request.title: Use valgrind to check for secret-dependent branching
pull_request.body:
Here's one way to use Valgrind to check for secret-dependent branching (and resolve #812). It's based on  Moritz Neikes [TIMECOP](https://post-apocalyptic-crypto.org/timecop/index.html).

The idea behind TIMECOP is that if you tell Valgrind that secret data resides in uninitialized memory, then Valgrind will tell you when your program branches on secret data.

SUPERCOP's implementation of TIMECOP introduced "classify" and "declassify" terminology for the operation of telling Valgrind that memory is secret or non-secret. I've replicated that terminology by defining two macros in oqs.h:

```c
#define OQS_TIMECOP_CLASSIFY(addr, len)  VALGRIND_MAKE_MEM_UNDEFINED(addr, len)
#define OQS_TIMECOP_DECLASSIFY(addr, len)  VALGRIND_MAKE_MEM_DEFINED(addr, len)
```

Every secret can ultimately be traced back to a call to randombytes, so we can tell Valgrind that secrets reside in uninitialized memory by defining our own randombytes, e.g.

```c
void TEST_KEM_randombytes(uint8_t *random_array, size_t bytes_to_read) {
  OQS_randombytes_system(random_array, bytes_to_read);
  OQS_TIMECOP_CLASSIFY(random_array, bytes_to_read);
}
```
and making it the default
```c
  OQS_randombytes_custom_algorithm(&TEST_KEM_randombytes);
```

I've done this in test_kem.c and test_sig.c. If you run the new test_kem or test_sig outside of Valgrind there's no change. But in Valgrind you'll see something like this:

```sh
$ valgrind ./tests/test_kem sntrup761
[...]
== Thread 2:
== Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)
==    at 0x2B4EBF: PQCLEAN_SNTRUP761_CLEAN_crypto_kem_keypair (kem.c:145)
==    by 0x10BCE8: kem_test_correctness (test_kem.c:94)
==    by 0x10C58B: test_wrapper (test_kem.c:177)
==    by 0x4CDAFA2: start_thread (pthread_create.c:486)
==    by 0x4DED4CE: clone (clone.S:95) 
[...]
```
(I've compiled with CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=debug to get the line numbers were secret branching occurs.)

Of course, some non-secret data is derived from calls to randombytes, and examining pqclean_sntrup761_clean/kem.c we see that line 145 is part of a rejection sampling loop and the branch is not secret. We can remove the false positive by calling OQS_TIMECOP_DECLASSIFY on the offending memory.

There's a different example of declassifying memory in Kyber512 in the first commit linked to this PR.

--- 

None of changes to oqs.h, test_kem.c, or test_sig.c introduce a dependency on Valgrind. Users can still compile test_kem and test_sig and run them outside of Valgrind. All we need are some header files that the Valgrind project provides, for this purpose, under a BSD license. I've added those to src/common/valgrind.

**TODO:**
- [x] Configure CMake to include the local valgrind/memcheck.h and valgrind/valgrind.h.
- [x] Add a compilation flag to completely remove calls to VALGRIND_MAKE_MEM_DEFINED. Compiling the schemes with "-DNVALGRIND" will do the trick. Alternatively we can change the definitions of OQS_TIMECOP_(DE)CLASSIFY in oqs.h with an ifdef.
- [ ] Flag false positives with OQS_TIMECOP_DECLASSIFY.
